title: New York Bans Sale of Flavored E-Cigarettes
text:
New York’s ban on flavored e-cigarettes and nicotine e-liquids went into effect immediately.

Amid a rash of pulmonary illnesses and several deaths in the U.S. linked to vaping and e-cigarette usage, New York state health officials on Tuesday passed an emergency regulation temporarily banning the sale of flavored e-cigarettes and nicotine e-liquids.

Members of the state’s Public Health and Health Planning Council approved the ban, arguing it would help stem a rise in e-cigarette use among minors, which they called a public health crisis. Michigan has also banned the sale of flavored e-cigarettes.

Some members of the Public Health and Health Planning Council said they were torn about approving the emergency measure, while others said it should have included a ban on menthol e-cigarettes. The ban went into effect immediately and is expected to last 90 days, with the expectation that it will be renewed absent a permanent legislative ban.

Glenn Martin, a member of the council and a doctor, said that e-cigarette use is a public health concern but voted against the regulation, calling the ban a “big public health experiment,” with a possible unintended consequence of the destruction of the e-cigarette retailing industry. “I’m just not convinced this is an emergency,” he said. Lawrence Brown, another council member and an addiction specialist, said public health has always been a process of slow progress. “I’m a bit concerned about doing nothing,” Dr. Brown said. Dozens of people who use or sell e-cigarette products showed up in person to the council’s meeting, which was held by videoconference at locations across the state, to protest the ban. They said flavored e-cigarettes have helped people stop smoking combustible cigarettes. Vape-shop owners said the ban would effectively put them out of business. Others said the ban was a form of prohibition and would push e-cigarette users back to cigarettes or drive the creation of flavored “vape juice” underground. Dennis Mink, who spoke before the council, said he smoked cigarettes for 48 years. He had tried medication, therapy, acupuncture and other measures to stop using cigarettes, he said. “I didn’t think vaping was going to work either,” he said. “You can quit. Nothing tops vaping!” The ban is effective immediately. Retailers will have until Oct. 4 before the state begins enforcing the new regulation. Retailers who violate the ban on sales will face fines of up to $2,000 per violation. Altria, the maker of Marlboro cigarettes, recently invested almost $13 billion in e-cigarette company Juul. Some experts say in its early days Juul mirrored the tobacco industry’s promotional playbook in an effort to hook young people. Photo: Natalia V.
